p: David Fisman, a professor at the Dalla Lana School of Public Health at the University of Toronto, notes that China contains many varied ecosystems where exposures might act in different ways. “It makes sense that in colder areas, increasing temperature would force higher transmission rates,” says Fisman, who was not involved in the study. He adds that warmer temperatures can lead to an “environmental sweet spot” that correlates with maximal stability for the viruses.
